Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Developing a modeling framework for evaluation of low impact development practices

POR.DRECONTENT:
Developing a modeling framework for evaluation of low impact development practices

Urban expansion has major implications for water resources and water quality in a watershed. Low impact development (LID) is an approach to land development that would help mitigate the increasing impact of urbanization. LID refers to a series of best management practices (BMPs) that could be used to conserve and protect the integrity of natural landscape features with reduced planning and design costs. These practices include green roofs, bioretention systems, grass swales, permeable pavements, rain barrels, pocket wetlands, etc.

 

Evaluation of BMPs is generally accomplished through monitoring and modeling studies. Monitoring-based studies may be the most accurate method to assess the effectiveness of LID practices, but they have limitations due to high costs and variability in the performance of LID practices induced by variability in topographic, soil and weather conditions. Simulation modeling is one simple alternative for LID practice evaluation with reduced costs, time and resources. There is a variety of watershed models that can be used to assess the performance of LID practices at different spatial and temporal scales. However, there are no numerical guidelines to represent and evaluate these practices within the modeling framework, as well as reporting the results. This lack of standard methodology could results in modeling errors and may potentially mislead decision making in regard to watershed management planning, regulatory strategies, design and research.

 

Our study is proposing a numerical framework for the representation and evaluation of LID practices. The proposed framework is being developed within the Long-Term Hydrologic Impact Assessment (L-THIA) model to support evaluation of LID scenarios and inform a wide spectrum of planning, regulatory, research, and engineering efforts. This methodology can be used in simple and complex models to obtain information about the effectiveness of LID practices for water resources planning and management. At the current stage this study has yielded the following outcomes:

Ahiablame, L., B. Engel, and I. Chaubey. (2011). Low Impact Development: What Do We Know? Urban Water Journal, Submitted (pending revision).

Ahiablame, L., B. Engel, and I. Chaubey. (2011). A Modeling Framework to Evaluate Low Impact Development Practices. Presented at The Ohio Stormwater Conference, Columbus, Ohio, May 12-13.

 Additional grant:

Ahiablame, L.M. (2010-2011). Modeling methods to evaluate low impact development. [Proposal]: PI, Illinois-Indiana Sea Grant College Program Research & Outreach Development and Capacity Building Projects (IISG) [funded: $6,000].
